segment.source: How to set up automatic detection for DHCP or DNS servers using IEAK 11 in your organization.
segment.target: How to set up automatic detection for DHCP or DNS servers using IEAK 11 in your organization.

segment.source: Set up auto detection for DHCP or DNS servers using IEAK 11 (Internet Explorer Administration Kit 11 for IT Pros)
segment.target: Set up auto detection for DHCP or DNS servers using IEAK 11 (Internet Explorer Administration Kit 11 for IT Pros)

segment.source: Set up auto detection for DHCP or DNS servers using IEAK 11
segment.target: Set up auto detection for DHCP or DNS servers using IEAK 11

segment.source: Set up your network to automatically detect and customize Internet Explorer 11 when it’s first started.
segment.target: Set up your network to automatically detect and customize Internet Explorer 11 when it’s first started.

segment.source: Automatic detection is supported on both Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) and Domain Name System (DNS), letting your servers detect and set up your employee’s browser settings from a central location, using a configuration URL (.ins file) or a JavaScript proxy configuration file (.js, .jvs, or .pac).
segment.target: Automatic detection is supported on both Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) and Domain Name System (DNS), letting your servers detect and set up your employee’s browser settings from a central location, using a configuration URL (.ins file) or a JavaScript proxy configuration file (.js, .jvs, or .pac).

segment.source: Before you can set up your environment to use automatic detection, you need to turn the feature on.
segment.target: Before you can set up your environment to use automatic detection, you need to turn the feature on.

segment.source: To turn on the automatic detection feature
segment.target: To turn on the automatic detection feature

segment.source: Open Internet Explorer Administration Kit 11 (IEAK 11), run the IE Customization Wizard 11 and on the Automatic Configuration page, check Automatically detect configuration settings.
segment.target: Open Internet Explorer Administration Kit 11 (IEAK 11), run the IE Customization Wizard 11 and on the Automatic Configuration page, check Automatically detect configuration settings.

segment.source: For more information, see Use the Automatic Configuration page in the IEAK 11 Wizard.
segment.target: For more information, see Use the Automatic Configuration page in the IEAK 11 Wizard.

segment.source: Automatic detection on DHCP and DNS servers
segment.target: Automatic detection on DHCP and DNS servers

segment.source: Automatic detection works even if the browser wasn't originally set up or installed by the administrator.
segment.target: Automatic detection works even if the browser wasn't originally set up or installed by the administrator.

segment.source: Using DHCP servers: For local area network (LAN)-based users.
segment.target: Using DHCP servers: For local area network (LAN)-based users.

segment.source: This server type lets you specify your global and subnet TCP/IP parameters centrally, defining your users' parameters by using reserved addresses.
segment.target: This server type lets you specify your global and subnet TCP/IP parameters centrally, defining your users' parameters by using reserved addresses.

segment.source: By doing it this way, a computer can move between subnets, automatically reconfiguring for TCP/IP when it starts.
segment.target: By doing it this way, a computer can move between subnets, automatically reconfiguring for TCP/IP when it starts.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Your DHCP servers must support the DHCPINFORM message, to obtain the DHCP options.
segment.target: Your DHCP servers must support the DHCPINFORM message, to obtain the DHCP options.

segment.source: Using DNS servers: For users on dial-up connections.
segment.target: Using DNS servers: For users on dial-up connections.

segment.source: This server type uses a set of protocols and services on a TCP/IP network, which lets users search for other computers by using hierarchical, user-friendly names (hosts), instead of numeric IP addresses.
segment.target: This server type uses a set of protocols and services on a TCP/IP network, which lets users search for other computers by using hierarchical, user-friendly names (hosts), instead of numeric IP addresses.

segment.source: To use this, you have to set up either the host record or the CNAME alias record in the DNS database file.
segment.target: To use this, you have to set up either the host record or the CNAME alias record in the DNS database file.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: DHCP has a higher priority than DNS for automatic configuration.
segment.target: DHCP has a higher priority than DNS for automatic configuration.

segment.source: If DHCP provides the URL to a .pac, .jvs, .js, or .ins configuration file, the process stops and the DNS lookup doesn't happen.
segment.target: If DHCP provides the URL to a .pac, .jvs, .js, or .ins configuration file, the process stops and the DNS lookup doesn't happen.

segment.source: To set up automatic detection for DHCP servers
segment.target: To set up automatic detection for DHCP servers

segment.source: Open the DHCP Administrative Tool, create a new option type, using the code number 252, and then associate it with the URL to your configuration file.
segment.target: Open the DHCP Administrative Tool, create a new option type, using the code number 252, and then associate it with the URL to your configuration file.

segment.source: For detailed instructions about how to do this, see Create an option 252 entry in DHCP.
segment.target: For detailed instructions about how to do this, see Create an option 252 entry in DHCP.

segment.source: Examples:
segment.target: Examples:

segment.source: http://www.microsoft.com/webproxy.pac
segment.target: http://www.microsoft.com/webproxy.pac

segment.source: http://marketing/config.ins
segment.target: http://marketing/config.ins

segment.source: http://123.4.567.8/account.pac
segment.target: http://123.4.567.8/account.pac

segment.source: For more detailed info about how to set up your DHCP server, see your server documentation.
segment.target: For more detailed info about how to set up your DHCP server, see your server documentation.

segment.source: To set up automatic detection for DNS servers
segment.target: To set up automatic detection for DNS servers

segment.source: In your DNS database file, the file that’s used to associate your host (computer) names to static IP addresses in a zone, you need to create a host record named, WPAD.
segment.target: In your DNS database file, the file that’s used to associate your host (computer) names to static IP addresses in a zone, you need to create a host record named, WPAD.

segment.source: This record contains entries for all of the hosts that require static mappings, such as workstations, name servers, and mail servers.
segment.target: This record contains entries for all of the hosts that require static mappings, such as workstations, name servers, and mail servers.

segment.source: It also has the IP address to the web server storing your automatic configuration (.js, .jvs, .pac, or .ins) file.
segment.target: It also has the IP address to the web server storing your automatic configuration (.js, .jvs, .pac, or .ins) file.

segment.source: The syntax is:
segment.target: The syntax is:

segment.source: -OR-
segment.target: -OR-

segment.source: Create a canonical name (CNAME) alias record, named WPAD.
segment.target: Create a canonical name (CNAME) alias record, named WPAD.

segment.source: This record lets you use more than one name to point to a single host, letting you host both an FTP server and a web server on the same computer.
segment.target: This record lets you use more than one name to point to a single host, letting you host both an FTP server and a web server on the same computer.

segment.source: It also includes the resolved name (not the IP address) of the server storing your automatic configuration (.pac) file.
segment.target: It also includes the resolved name (not the IP address) of the server storing your automatic configuration (.pac) file.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: For more info about creating a WPAD entry, see Creating a WPAD entry in DNS.
segment.target: For more info about creating a WPAD entry, see Creating a WPAD entry in DNS.

segment.source: After the database file propagates to the server, the DNS name, resolves to the server name that includes your automatic configuration file.
segment.target: After the database file propagates to the server, the DNS name, resolves to the server name that includes your automatic configuration file.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: IE11 creates a default URL template based on the host name,wpad.
segment.target: IE11 creates a default URL template based on the host name,wpad.

segment.source: For example, .
segment.target: For example, .

segment.source: Because of this, you need to set up a file or redirection point in your web server WPAD record, named wpad.dat.
segment.target: Because of this, you need to set up a file or redirection point in your web server WPAD record, named wpad.dat.

segment.source: The wpad.dat record delivers the contents of your automatic configuration file.
segment.target: The wpad.dat record delivers the contents of your automatic configuration file.
